Utterance: Hi! It’s great to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi! I’ve been good. I’ve been practicing the breathing exercises before bed.
That’s fantastic! How has that been working for you?
It’s helped a lot. I feel more relaxed, and I’ve been sleeping better.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s wonderful news! Consistent practice can make a significant difference. Have you noticed any other changes in your daily routine?
I’ve been more focused at work and school, which is nice.
That’s great to hear! It sounds like you’re making some positive strides. Have you been able to maintain the earlier wake-up time?
Yes, I’ve been waking up at 6:00 AM most days.
Excellent! That’s a big commitment. How do you feel about your mornings now?
They feel less chaotic, and I actually enjoy having that quiet time.
That’s wonderful! It’s great to hear that you’re finding joy in that part of your day. Now, how is football going? Have you been able to join a league or practice more?
I found a local league! I’m really excited to start.
That’s amazing! How do you feel about being part of a team again?
I feel really good about it. I think it’ll help me connect with others and have fun.
Absolutely! Being part of a team can provide a sense of community and support. When do you start?
Next week! I can’t wait.
That’s exciting! I’m looking forward to hearing about your experiences. Now, let’s talk about your son. How has your connection with him been since we last spoke?
It’s been great! We’ve been doing more activities together, like going to the park.
That sounds wonderful! Spending quality time together can really strengthen your bond. Have you noticed any changes in his behavior or mood?
He seems happier and more engaged. It’s nice to see.
That’s fantastic! It sounds like your involvement is making a positive impact. Have you had any challenges as a parent recently?
A few. Sometimes he gets frustrated with his schoolwork, and I have to remind him to stay patient.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: Patience can be tough for kids. How do you handle those moments?
I try to be calm and encourage him to take breaks when he gets too frustrated.
That’s a great approach! Encouraging breaks can help him reset and refocus. Now, let’s revisit the topic of stress. Have you encountered any new stressors since our last session?
Not really. Work has been steady, and I’m managing my time better.
That’s excellent! It sounds like you’re becoming more adept at handling stress. Have you found any new coping strategies that work for you?
I’ve been journaling a bit, just to get my thoughts out.
Journaling can be a great tool for processing emotions. How has that been for you?
It helps me clear my mind and reflect on my day.
That’s wonderful to hear! Reflection can lead to greater self-awareness. Is there anything specific you’ve been reflecting on lately?
I’ve been thinking about my goals and what I want to achieve this year.
That’s a healthy focus! What goals have you identified for yourself?
I want to finish my degree, improve my football skills, and be a better parent.
Those are all meaningful goals. How can we break those down into smaller, actionable steps?
For school, I can set aside specific study times. For football, I can practice a couple of times a week. And for parenting, I can plan more activities with my son.
Those sound like excellent plans! Setting specific times can help you stay on track. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I think that covers it for now.
Alright! I’m excited to hear about your progress in our next session. Remember to celebrate each small step you take. Take care!
Thank you! See you next time.
